content.text: Complete the table below to identify the physical quantities as scalars or vectors
Calculate the average speed of the ball between A and B
average speed = .........
Player B kicks the ball to player C
It travels with the same average speed
Calculate the time taken for the ball to travel from B to C
Suggest why the speed of the ball might change during its motion from A to
Discuss whether the average velocities, from A to B and from B to C, are the same

Fig. 1.1 shows the path of a football as it is kicked along the ground between three players. The distances between the players are shown on Fig. 1.1
The ball takes 1.2 s to travel from player A to player B
State **three** types of energy, other than gravitational potential energy, into which the electrical energy supplied to the motor is converted
The mass of the package is \(36\mathrm{kg}.\) Calculate the increase in the gravitational potential energy (p.e.) of the package when it is raised through a vertical height of \(2.4\mathrm{m}\)
The package is raised through the vertical height of \(2.4 \text{m}\) in 4.4 s. Calculate the power needed to raise the package

Assume that the power available to raise packages is constant. A package of mass greater than \(36\mathrm{kg}\) is raised through the same height. Suggest and explain the effect of this increase in mass on the operation of the belt
Fig. 2.1 shows a conveyor belt transporting a package to a raised platform. The belt is motor
Complete the following statement:
The moment of a force about a point is
multiplied by
On Fig. 3.1, draw an arrow to show the weight of bar B acting from its centre of mass.
State the distance \(d\) of the centre of mass of bar B from the pivot
Calculate the total clockwise moment, about the pivot, of the forces acting on bar B
total clockwise moment = .........
Calculate the downward force which the slab S exerts on the end of bar B
Suggest a change to the arrangement in Fig. 3.1 that would reduce the force required to lift the slab
[Total: 9]

Fig. 3.1 shows a uniform iron bar B of weight \(30 \text{N}\) and length \(1.40 \text{m}\). The bar is being used to lift one edge of a concrete slab S. A stone, placed \(0.20 \text{m}\) from one end of B, acts as a pivot. A force of \(40 \text{N}\) pushing down at the other end of B is just enough to lift the slab and hold it as shown
Explain what is meant by the statement: 'the specific latent heat of fusion of ice is 330 J/g'
State what is taking place in the regions of the graph from B to C, and from D to E
B to C
D to E
Use the information in the table to explain why the line DE is longer than the line BC
Use the information in the table to explain why the graph is steeper from A to C to D
[Total: 6]
A block of ice is taken from a freezer at \(-25^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\), placed in a metal container, and heated by a source of constant power
The graph in Fig. 4.1 shows how the temperature of the contents of the container changes with time. At point E on the graph the container is empty
Use the information in the table when answering this question

table.html:
specific heat capacity of ice2.0 J/(g°C)
specific heat capacity of water4.2 J/(g°C)
specific latent heat of fusion of ice330 J/g
specific latent heat of vaporisation of water2260 J/g

content.text: Describe the motion of the molecules of the gas

Calculate the new pressure of the gas
pressure = .........
Explain, in terms of the behaviour of the molecules, why the pressure has c

The piston is moved so that the new length of cylinder occupied by the gas is \(50 \text{cm}\). The temperature of the gas is unchanged
Fig. 5.1 shows a gas contained in a cylinder enclosed by a piston

At first, the length of cylinder containing the gas is \(100\mathrm{cm}.\) The pressure of the gas, shown by the pressure gauge, is \(300\mathrm{kPa}.\) The area of cross-section of the cylinder is \(0.12\mathrm{m}^2.\)
A long rope, fixed at one end, is being used by a student to demonstrate waves
State what the student does to the rope to produce the transverse wave
Fig. 6.1 shows a section of the rope when the transverse wave is present
Fig. 6.1
On Fig. 6.1, show
1. a distance, labelled \(\lambda\), corresponding to the wavelength of the wave,
2. a distance, labelled \(A\), corresponding to the amplitude of the wave
Suggest what the student could do to reduce the wavelength of the wave
The diagram in Fig. 6.2 represents waves on the surface of water in a ripple tank are travelling from deep water across a boundary into shallow water
Explain how the diagram shows that water waves travel more slowly in shallow water than in deep water
[Total: 7]
What is meant by the _focal length_ of a converging lens?
Fig. 7.1
Explain what is meant by a _real image_
Rays of light from point A on the object form point B on the image
On Fig. 6.1, draw
1. a ray to find the position of the converging lens, showing the lens as a vertical straight line in this position,
2. a ray to find the position of a principal focus of the lens, marking this position \(\mathbf{F}\),
3. a third possible ray from A to B
The distance between the object and the lens is increased. State any changes which take place in
1. the distance of the image from the lens,
2. the size of the image
[Total: 7]
An object is placed in front of a converging lens. A real image is formed, as shown in Fig. 7.1
The converging lens is not shown
What is meant by the _electromotive force_ (e.m.f.) of an electric power supply?
the current in the lamp,
